block.p: Islamic Militias Say They Have Seized Somali Capital After months of fierce fighting, Islamic militias declared that they had taken control of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, defeating the warlords widely believed to be backed by the United States and raising questions about whether the country will head down an extremist path.

European Incentives for Iran The European Union's chief diplomat, Javier Solana, arrived in Tehran with a package of incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow it to upgrade its aging air fleet through the purchase of civilian aircraft parts from an American company, Boeing.

Iraqi Jailed for Life in Abduction Iraq's Central Criminal Court imposed a life sentence on a man who apparently played a minor role in the kidnapping of Margaret Hassan, a British-Iraqi aid official.

New Philanthropy for Africa The Ford Foundation will announce the creation of a new philanthropic venture, led by Africans and based in Dakar, Senegal. The project aims to strengthen a network of nonprofit groups across the continent that seek to hold governments accountable.

U.S. Cites Germany on Slavery On the eve of the World Cup in Germany, the United States, in its report on forced labor and trafficking in persons, called Germany, which has legalized prostitution, ''a source, transit and destination country'' for prostitutes.
Justices to Rule on Schools Using Race for Admission The Supreme Court agreed to rule on what measures, if any, public school systems may use to maintain racial balance in individual schools.

Campaigns Get an Early Start Congressional campaigns have begun early and with unusual intensity this year in many districts across the country, reflecting a consensus in both parties that Republicans could lose control of the House and perhaps the Senate.
Former President Bill Clinton has committed to appear at about two dozen fund-raisers, hoping to collect at least $20 million for his party's drive to recapture Congress.

New Orleans Projects Dispute Hundreds of displaced public housing residents returned for the first time since Hurricane Katrina in an attempt to force New Orleans to reopen their storm-damaged apartments. The city, saying the projects are not ready, has refused.

Antipsychotics and Children The use of potent antipsychotic drugs to treat children and adolescents for problems like aggression and mood swings increased more than fivefold from 1993 to 2002, researchers are reporting.
Debate Over Wind Power Wind projects are in the midst of a huge growth spurt in many parts of the country, driven by government incentives to promote alternatives to fossil fuels.

Report on Medicaid Fraud Cites Partial Improvements A scathing federal report on New York State's efforts to root out Medicaid fraud expressed approval for certain changes the state has made over the last few years, but also described many of those changes as late in coming, inadequate and only partially implemented.

Weld Pressured to Quit Race Political pressure mounted on William F. Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, to quit the Republican race for New York governor as two of his most prominent backers defected to his Republican rival, and some of his own advisers said the race might be too expensive to win.

Life Term for Ex-Detectives Two highly decorated former New York City detectives were given sentences of life in prison by a Brooklyn federal judge for taking part in at least eight murders for the mob.

Saving Frogs in Carry-Ons In a race to save amphibians threatened by a lethal fungus, two conservationists from Atlanta recently packed their carry-ons with frogs rescued from a Central American rain forest -- squeezing some 150 into a suitcase -- and requested permission from airlines to travel with them in the cabin of the plane.

New Details on Lawsuit A lawsuit against Oxford Health Plans that was settled in 2003 has taken on new import in light of admissions by a plaintiff and prosecutors' charges against the law firm Milberg Weiss.

Concerns About Inflation Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he is worried about the danger of higher prices.

Columns: John Tierney; Nicholas D. Kristof.
